**Youngest Person to Reach South Pole Solo Completes Journey**

Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles and brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, has become the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo and unsupported. He completed his 702-mile trek on Christmas Day, more than 12 days ahead of schedule.

Sears, who played tennis professionally before joining the Army, pulled a sled and supplies for 38 days through extreme weather conditions, including 150mph winds and temperatures of -50°C. The first part of his journey, from Hercules Inlet to the South Pole, is considered the most dangerous due to riddled crevasses and glaciers.

Despite hitting a wall on Christmas Eve, just 38km from the pole, Sears persevered and reached his destination the following day. He described his experience as "absolutely chuffed to pieces" and said he was "practically good" until he hit the wall.

Sears' journey was not only a personal achievement but also a fundraising effort for the Gurkha Welfare Trust, which aims to rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. He raised over £33,500 for the cause.

After his journey, Sears is expected to take a few weeks to process his experience, having spent nearly six weeks alone in a tent. He is looking forward to a shower and a meal, saying he has been dreaming about it since day three.

The Guinness Book of Records has yet to confirm whether Sears' feat will make it into the record books.assistant

"It is unfathomable that somebody in today's society would walk into a church when people are having a prayer meeting and take their lives," Mullen told reporters. "I can assure you that we're going to do everything in our power to find this individual, to lock him up and to make sure he doesn't hurt anyone else." Mayor Joe Riley called the suspect "one hateful person," describing the shooting as "the most dastardly act that one could possibly imagine." In other developments: Helicopters are circling Charleston in the search for the suspect, who's described as a white male, around 21 years old, slender, clean-shaven, and wearing a gray sweatshirt, blue jeans, and Timberland boots, the Guardian reports. Police say he is "obviously extremely dangerous." State Sen. Clementa Pinckney, the church's pastor, was in the church at the time of the attack, and State House Minority leader Todd Rutherford tells the AP that the lawmaker was among those killed. The 41-year-old "never had anything bad to say about anybody, even when I thought he should," Rutherford says. "He was always out doing work either for his parishioners or his constituents. He touched everybody." The Post and Courier has more on the history of the church, which it calls the "spiritual home to one of the oldest and largest black congregations south of Baltimore," and which many in the city call "Mother Emanuel." Its roots go back to 1816, and it was burned after one of its founders tried to organize a slave revolt in 1822. Members went underground until after the Civil War, when the church adopted the name "Emanuel." Jeb Bush has canceled a Charleston campaign appearance scheduled for today, the New York Times reports. A campaign aide for Hillary Clinton says she was in the city yesterday but left before the shooting.
